infodynamics.measures.continuous

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, TransferEntropyCalculator
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian, TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo

    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
extends java.lang.Object
implements TransferEntropyCalculator
    A Transfer Entropy (TE) calculator (implementing TransferEntropyCalculator) which is affected using a given Conditional Mutual Information (MI) calculator (implementing ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate) to make the calculations.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculator, except that in the constructor(s) for this class the implementation for a ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate must be supplied.

    This class may be used directly, however users are advised that several child classes are available which already plug-in the various conditional MI estimators to provide TE calculators (taking specific caution associated with each type of estimator):

    • TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian
    • TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov
    TODO Delete TransferEntropyCalculatorCommon once we've switched everything over to use this? Might be useful to leave it after all, and move common functionality from here to there.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier, email, www

      • k

        protected int k
        Length of past destination history to consider (embedding length)

      • k_tau

        protected int k_tau
        Embedding delay to use between elements of the destination embeding vector. We're hard-coding a delay of 1 between the history vector and the next observation however.

      • l

        protected int l
        Length of past source history to consider (embedding length)

      • l_tau

        protected int l_tau
        Embedding delay to use between elements of the source embeding vector.

        protected int delay
        Source-destination next observation delay

        protected int startTimeForFirstDestEmbedding
        Time index of the last point in the destination embedding of the first (destination past, source past, destination next) tuple than can be taken from any set of time-series observations.

        protected boolean debug
        Whether we're in debugging mode

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets properties for the TE calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • Any properties accepted by TransferEntropyCalculator.setProperty(String, String)
        • Or properties accepted by the underlying ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.setProperty(String, String) implementation.

        Note: further properties may be defined by child classes.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Specified by:

        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property.

      • setObservations

        public void setObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF for the channel measure. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.

        The supplied series are certainly time-series for time-series measures such as transfer entropy, however may be simply a set of separate observations for the mutual information without a time interpretation.

        Specified by:
        setObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        public void startAddObservations()
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Signal that we will add in the samples for computing the PDF from several disjoint time-series or trials via calls to "addObservations" rather than "setObservations" type methods (defined by the child interfaces and classes).
        Specified by:

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(). Call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination,
                   int startTime,
                   int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with, as a subset of the supplied arrays. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(). Call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of steps from and including startTime to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setObservations

        public void setObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination,
                   boolean[] sourceValid,
                   boolean[] destValid)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator

        Sets the single set of observations to compute the PDFs from, but only where these observations are indicated to be valid. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.

        The supplied series are certainly time-series for time-series measures such as transfer entropy, however may be simply a set of separate observations for the mutual information without a time interpretation.

        Specified by:
        setObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        sourceValid - array (with indices the same as source) indicating whether the source at that index is valid.
        destValid - array (with indices the same as destination) indicating whether the destination at that index is valid.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeStartAndEndTimePairs

        public java.util.Vector<int[]> computeStartAndEndTimePairs(boolean[] sourceValid,
                                                  boolean[] destValid)
                                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute a vector of start and end pairs of time points, between which we have valid series of both source and destinations. (I.e. all points within the embedding vectors must be valid, even if the invalid points won't be included in any tuples)

        Made public so it can be used if one wants to compute the number of observations prior to setting the observations.

        Parameters:
        sourceValid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid for the source;
        destValid - as described for sourceValid
        Returns:
        a vector for start and end time pairs of valid series of observations.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon

        Computes the local values of the implemented channel measure, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local TE values. If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then this time-series will have zero entries until the source and destination embedding vectors are defined.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[] newSourceObservations,
                                             double[] newDestObservations)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator
        Compute the local measure values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        newSourceObservations - series of observations for the source variable (indexed by time or observation index)
        newDestObservations - series of observations for the destination variable (indexed by time or observation index) Length must match newSourceObservations, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the channel measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value. (Precise null hypothesis varies between MI and TE).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeSignificance(int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate AIS calculations.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the channel measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value. (Precise null hypothesis varies between MI and TE).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the source values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by ChannelCalculatorCommon.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • getLastAverage

        public double getLastAverage()
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Return the channel measure last calculated in a call to ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeAverageLocalOfObservations() or ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations() after the previous ChannelCalculatorCommon.initialise() call.
        Specified by:
        getLastAverage in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        the last computed channel measure value

      • getNumObservations

        public int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to #setObservations(double[]), #addObservations(double[]) etc.

        Note that the number of samples may not be equal to the length of time-series supplied (e.g. for transfer entropy, where we need to accumulate a number of samples for the past history of the destination).

        Specified by:
        getNumObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        Specified by:
        getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
